Bilingual Round Table Discussion (Part I) Index [Index]

body.value: Pierre de Grandpré discusses the goal of his critique
De Grandpré discusses the creator's review
De Grandpré discusses how poetry is an essential part of civilization
De Grandpré disucsses 19th-century critics' discourse
De Grandpré discusses how criticism turns into philosophy or science
Jean-Paul Pilon comments on de Grandpré distinction between academic and everyday criticism
De Grandpré responds to Pilon in regard to his view of criticism
Pilon asks de Grandpré about the critique of poetry
De Grandpré answers Pilon about the critique of poetry
Pilon asks de Grandpré about the echo of the critique of poetry
De Grandpré asks Pilon to elaborate on his point of view
Livesay comments about the differences between Québec and the rest of the country in regard to the critique of poetry [English]
De Grandpré responds in regard to those differences between French and English critiques of poetry
De Grandpré asks D.G. Jones to elaborate on the differences between criticism of newspapers compared to others
Jones answers de Grandpré on the nature of criticism [English]
De Grandpré asks Cécile Cloutier about criticism and the critics
Cloutier answers by saying how poets want the critics to understand their work
De Grandpré asks Pilon if we should wish for an assertive critic
Pilon answewrs by saying that he expects little from critics
De Grandpré asks Livesay if she thinks the critique can be interesting for the public but not for the poet
Livesay answers on the critique's role [English]
De Grandpré comments on how the poet should ask himself about the role of the critique
Pilon responds by saying that the role of the critique is to act as an intermediary between the public and the poet
De Grandpré comments on the roles the critique plays in literature [Incomplete]
Jones responds that critical activity is useful and necessary [English]
De Grandpré asks Cloutier whether critical judgement seems less useful now
Cloutier answers that critical judgement is just as useful as the others
De Grandpré asks Cloutier if she believes in the useful role of judgement in literature
Cloutier answers that she believes judgement is allowed in the critique of literature
De Grandpré asks the speakers what their position is on the new criticism
Pilon answers that he has no opinion on the matter
De Grandpré comments that the critique can lose the esthetic value of the work
Pilon responds that he thinks we forget to read the work when it comes to the critique
De Grandpré comments on the critique of aesthetics, which can lead to the loss of sight of the work
Pilon responds that we shouldn't lose sight of the work
De Grandpré comments that criticism can come to touch on different human sciences
Jones responds on the positive side of having different points of view [English]
De Grandpré asks Jones if qualifying the poem as superior to the critique
Jones answers that the word inferior might be a better word [English]
Livesay comments on what lowers the standards of criticism [English]
Jones answers on where French Canadian criticism differs from English Canadian criticism [English]
De Grandpré asks Pilon on the limits of creator-only criticism
Pilon answers on the distinction between information criticism and academic criticism
De Grandpré responds that there should be an information criticism and an in-depth criticism
Pilon responds that academic criticism brings more to the creator
De Grandpré responds that poetic literature needs criticism
Pilon responds that he has nothing to add
De Grandpré asks Pilon if there are enough critics who focus on poetry in French Canada
Cloutier answers that there isn't enough good academic criticism in French Canadian poetry
Pilon responds in agreement with Cloutier
De Grandpré asks Livesay if there are enough critics who focus on poetry in English Canada
Livesay answers on the lack of continuity in the criticism of English Canadian poetry [English]
Jones comments on the lack of continuing criticism [English]
Livesay asks Jones about the change from written poetry to oral poetry and its effects on criticism [English]
Jones answers that he has no theory on the subject [English]
De Grandpré asks Livesay if it's possible to have a critique of oral poetry
Livesay answers if there is even a criticism of oral poetry [English]
De Grandpré comments on good criticism to good poetry
Jones comments on the crisis in criticism
De Grandpré comments on the role of the critic
Pilon responds on different time periods where there are less critics [Incomplete]
De Grandpré comments on what makes a balanced critique
Pilon comments that many critics became creators
De Grandpré responds that it wasn't the critique that brought them to be creators
Pilon comments more on critics who become creators
De Grandpré asks the public for questions on the relationship between poetry and criticism
[unintelligible]
De Grandpré responds that criticism is an essential function of literature
Pilon mentions Le Poème pulvérisé de René Char
De Grandpré comments on how the creator's critique can be a good critique
Audience comments on the role of the critic [English]
De Grandpré responds on what the role of the critic should be
Audience comments on canadian poets not responding well to criticism [Incomplete]
Audience comments on poets dismissing criticism [English]
De Grandpré comments that a critic is also an artist
Jones recomments on the crisis in criticism [English]
Livesay comments on the steps taken to reduce the gulf in poetry [English]
Applause and closing remarks
C.H. Moore discusses the lack of models for canadian writers [English]
Earle Birney discusses the ways poets communicate [English]
Birney discusses aboriginal dancing in relation to poetry
Birney discusses how poets get together to discuss poetry
Birney discusses his skepticism on how poets influence their generation
Birney discusses the communication emerging from poetry [Incomplete]
Earle Birney, in mid-discussion, discusses musical notation in Medieval poems
Birney discusses mixed media in concrete poems
Birney introduces Kurt Schwitters' poem that imitates bird vocalizations
Birney performs his version of Schwitters' "Ursonate"
Birney introduces E. E. Cummings' poetic experimentation with the human voice
Birney performs Cummings' "VII" from One Times One
Birney introduces "VIII"
Birney performs "VIII"
Birney discusses Cummings' attempts to express the immediacy of experience
Birney performs "XXVII"
Birney introduces Michael McClure's poems written in the "beast language"
Birney performs an unknown poem by McClure
Birney introduces Bob Cobbing's "sound-poem sequence"
Birney performs an unknown poem by Cobbing
Birney introduces his poem "orphiasco", a satirical response to Ivy Compton-Burnett's novel
Birney performs "orphiasco"
Birney discusses on the inner turmoil and satisfaction experienced by a poet when writing
Birney discusses poetry that is involved with visual arts in itself
Birney discusses his visual poem, "like an eddy my words turn about your bright rock"
Birney promotes his collection, Pnomes, Jukollages, and Other Stunzas
Birney performs "Campus Theatre Steps" from the collection
Birney discusses "Pnome" from the collection
Birney performs an unknown poem
Birney discusses the similarities and differences between Stephen Scobie's poem and his own
Birney introduces an unknown "gag poem"
Birney performs the poem using his body language
Birney promotes Scobie's poetry exhibition
Birney introduces "The Birth of God" by Lionel Kearns
Birney asks the audience to identify the title for this poem
Audience Member 1 answers the question correctly
Birney asks Audience Member 1 about his understanding of the poem
Audience Member 1 answers that he thinks the poem dramatizing the interpenetration of one and zero
Birney responds by highlighting the techniques used in the poem
Audience Member 1 comments on Scobie's exhibition
Birney re-promotes his collection and addresses the audience
Applause
